Early life and education

William Howard Taft was born on March 27, 1857, in Cincinnati, Ohio, to Alphonso Taft and Louisa Maria Harvey Taft. His father was a wealthy lawyer who had served as secretary of war under President Ulysses S. Grant before becoming a federal judge. Taft grew up in a family that valued education and intellectual pursuits, and he excelled academically throughout his childhood. He attended private schools in Cincinnati before enrolling at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, where he studied law and graduated with honors in 1880.

Family background

William Howard Taft was born on March 27, 1857, in Cincinnati, Ohio, to Alphonso Taft and Louisa Torney Taft. His father served as Secretary of War under President Ulysses S. Grant before becoming a federal judge. Taft grew up in a wealthy family and attended Yale University, where he played football and joined the Skull and Bones society. After graduating from law school, he began his legal career in Cincinnati before being appointed Solicitor General of the United States by President Benjamin Harrison.

Taft married Anna Elizabeth Dickinson in 1886, and they had three children together. He was known for his love of food and drink, especially ice cream and beer. Despite his large frame (he weighed over 300 pounds), he enjoyed playing sports and was an avid golfer. In addition to his work as a lawyer and politician, Taft also wrote several books, including “The Payne-Aldrich Tariff Act” and “Our Chief Magistrate.”

Taft suffered from health problems throughout his life, including heart disease and diabetes. He died on January 8, 1930, in Washington D.C., after suffering a stroke while attending a dinner party at the home of his friend, former President Theodore Roosevelt.

Career as a lawyer

After graduating from Yale Law School in 1878, William Howard Taft became an attorney in Cincinnati, Ohio. He quickly gained recognition for his legal expertise and was appointed to the bench of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in 1890 by President Benjamin Harrison. In this role, he wrote over 250 opinions that were highly regarded for their clarity and accuracy.

Taft also served as the solicitor general of the United States under President Theodore Roosevelt, where he argued several cases before the Supreme Court. One notable case he argued was the landmark decision of Lochner v. New York, which challenged the constitutionality of a New York law limiting the hours that bakery workers could work. Although Taft ultimately lost the case, his arguments helped establish the power of judicial review in American jurisprudence.

In addition to his work as a lawyer, Taft was also active in politics. He served as the Prosecuting Attorney of Hamilton County, Ohio from 1881-1885, and later ran unsuccessfully for Governor of Ohio in 1894. He was then elected as the 27th President of the United States in 1908, becoming the first president to be born in the 20th century.

Political career before presidency

William Howard Taft was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1879 and served for two years before being appointed by President Benjamin Harrison as a judge on the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals. In 1896, he was nominated by the Republican Party as their candidate for president, but lost to Democratic nominee William Jennings Bryan. He then served as the Governor-General of the Philippines from 1901 until 1902, where he oversaw the implementation of reforms aimed at improving the lives of Filipinos under American rule. After returning to the United States, he resumed his legal career and became known for his expertise in antitrust law.

Presidency (1909-1913)

As President of the United States, William Howard Taft faced several challenges during his presidency from 1909 to 1913. One of the most significant issues he had to deal with was the conflict between labor and management in the country’s industries. He also had to navigate the complexities of foreign policy, particularly regarding the ongoing arms race between Europe’s major powers. Additionally, Taft oversaw the creation of new federal agencies such as the Federal Trade Commission and the Bureau of Mines. Despite these accomplishments, Taft’s presidency is perhaps best known for its impact on the Supreme Court. In 1905, Taft appointed Edward Douglass White to replace Associate Justice John Harlan, who had resigned due to ill health. This appointment resulted in the court becoming more conservative, which pleased many Republicans but angered progressives who felt that the court was becoming too powerful. During Taft’s presidency, the Supreme Court issued decisions that greatly expanded the power of corporations over individuals, including the famous decision in Lochner v. New York, which struck down a state law limiting the hours that bakery workers could work. Overall, Taft’s presidency was marked by significant achievements and controversies, cementing his place in American history as one of the nation’s most important leaders.

Post-presidential career

After leaving office in 1913, William Howard Taft returned to his home state of Ohio and resumed practicing law. He also served as the sixth chief justice of the United States Supreme Court from 1921 until his death in 1930. During this time, he wrote over 400 opinions, many of which had long-lasting impact on American jurisprudence. In addition to his work on the bench, Taft was involved in various other projects, including serving as an arbitrator for labor disputes and advocating for civil service reform. He remained active in politics throughout his life, supporting Republican candidates such as Calvin Coolidge and Herbert Hoover. Despite being out of office, Taft maintained a strong influence on American political and legal affairs for decades after his presidency ended.

Personal life

William Howard Taft was born on March 27, 1857, in Cincinnati, Ohio, to Alphonso and Louisa Taft. He had one younger brother, Charles Phelps Taft II. His father was a wealthy civil engineer who had built several bridges across the Ohio River, while his mother came from a family of modest means. Taft grew up in a large house on West Seventh Street in Cincinnati, where he developed a close relationship with his mother, whom he described as his best friend.

Taft was known for being a very tall man, standing at 6 feet 1 inch (1.85 meters) tall. He was also overweight throughout most of his adult life, weighing around 300 pounds (140 kilograms) during his presidency. Despite his size, Taft was an avid sportsman and enjoyed playing tennis, golf, and baseball. He was also known for his sense of humor and easygoing personality.

In 1900, Taft married his childhood sweetheart, Nellie Herron, whom he had met when they were both teenagers. The couple had three children together, including two sons and a daughter. Taft was a devoted husband and father, and he often spoke fondly of his family in public speeches and interviews.

Legacy

William Howard Taft is widely regarded as one of the most influential U.S. presidents in history. His legacy has had a profound impact on American politics and society. Some of his notable achievements include:

1. The establishment of the U.S. Bureau of Mines, which regulated mining safety and health standards for workers.

2. The creation of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which was the first federal appeals court established by Congress.

3. The signing of the Mann-Elkins Act, which granted the Interior Department authority over natural resources such as oil, gas, and coal.

Taft also played an important role in international affairs during his presidency. He negotiated the Hay-Bunau-Varilla Treaty with Panama, which secured control of the Panama Canal Zone for the United States. Additionally, he supported the creation of the League of Nations, which was intended to be a global organization that would promote peace and cooperation between nations. However, his proposal for this league failed to gain support from other countries, and it was not established until many years later. Overall, William Howard Taft’s legacy continues to influence American politics and society today, particularly in areas related to labor rights, environmental protection, and international relations.

Notable achievements

William Howard Taft was one of the most influential presidents in American history. He is best known for his significant contributions to constitutional law and his impact on the Supreme Court. During his time as President, he appointed two justices to the court who had a lasting influence on its decisions, including Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., who wrote the majority opinion in the landmark case of Lochner v. New York.

Taft also played an important role in shaping international relations during his presidency. He negotiated the Treaty of Washington with Japan, which normalized trade between the two countries and opened up new markets for American goods. Additionally, he helped establish the Dollar Diplomacy policy, which aimed to promote American economic interests abroad through diplomatic means rather than military intervention.

Finally, Taft is also remembered for his leadership in promoting civil service reform. As President, he established the Civil Service Commission, which was responsible for enforcing merit-based hiring practices throughout the federal government. This initiative paved the way for future reforms that would help ensure fairness and accountability in the public sector.
